Title.evidence: We tested the hypothesis that a virtual reality program (AppliedVR, Los Angeles, CA) decreases acute postoperative pain and opioid requirements in patients recovering from hip arthroplasty.

Trial_Design.evidence: Participating patients were randomized to 2–8-minute-long three-dimensional immersive virtual reality relaxation and distraction video presentations.

Participants.evidence: We evaluated 106 adults who were recovering from elective primary total hip arthroplasty.

Intervention.evidence: randomized to 2–8-minute-long three-dimensional immersive virtual reality relaxation and distraction video presentations or to two-dimensional presentations of nature short films.

Objective.evidence: We tested the hypothesis that a virtual reality program (AppliedVR, Los Angeles, CA) decreases acute postoperative pain and opioid requirements in patients recovering from hip arthroplasty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Our primary outcome was pain after virtual reality or sham video presentations, adjusted for pre-treatment scores.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 52 patients were randomized to virtual reality distraction and relaxation, and 54 were assigned to two-dimensional sham presentations.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Virtual reality presentations were not found to affect pain scores, with an estimated difference in means (virtual reality minus sham video) of −0.1 points [95% CI: −0.5, 0.2, P=0.391] on a 0–10 scale.
